articles.headline: Further Delays for Employers in Health Law
articles.snippet: The Obama administration announced that it would again delay the mandate for employers to provide health insurance to employees, giving medium-size companies extra time to comply.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration announced that it would again delay the mandate for employers to provide health insurance to employees, giving medium-size companies extra time to comply.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced on Monday that it would postpone enforcement of a federal requirement for medium-size employers to provide health insurance to employees and allow larger employers more flexibility in how they provide coverage.

articles.headline: Labor Battle at Kellogg Plant in Memphis Drags On
articles.snippet: Kellogg is pressuring for what Caterpillar, Boeing and Detroit’s automakers have sought in recent years — to reduce blue-collar compensation packages.
articles.abstract: Kellogg is pressuring for what Caterpillar, Boeing and Detroit’s automakers have sought in recent years — to reduce blue-collar compensation packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — It’s 11 a.m. and a bone-chilling 18 degrees as Joey Watts, wearing a picket sign that says “Locked Out,” trudges across an overpass overlooking the cereal factory, which has a big neon sign spelling out Kellogg’s in its red signature logo.

articles.headline: Life Coaches for the Entrepreneurial Set
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs, executives and the wealthy seek help to live better, make more money or determine what’s next.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs, executives and the wealthy seek help to live better, make more money or determine what’s next.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 2005, Ali Riaz, then president of a search technology company that would eventually be sold to Microsoft, was having dinner with one of his board members when he admitted that he was struggling with managing everything that running a fast-growing, cutting-edge company entailed.

articles.headline: Winter Storms Cause Havoc for Fliers
articles.snippet: Last month, nearly 40,000 flights were canceled in the United States, about four times the previous two January totals, according to FlightAware, and more snow and ice is forecast this week in the South and Northeast.
articles.abstract: Last month, nearly 40,000 flights were canceled in the United States, about four times the previous two January totals, according to FlightAware, and more snow and ice is forecast this week in the South and Northeast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like millions of travelers this winter, Billy Bauer has felt the full effects of the nation’s cold weather.

articles.headline: Revelations by AOL Boss Raise Fears Over Privacy
articles.snippet: AOL’s chief, Tim Armstrong, set off a firestorm among American workers by publicly revealing information about medical costs for two babies covered by company health plans.
articles.abstract: AOL’s chief, Tim Armstrong, set off a firestorm among American workers by publicly revealing information about medical costs for two babies covered by company health plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, apologized last weekend for publicly revealing sensitive health care details about two employees to explain why the online media giant had decided to cut benefits. He even reinstated the benefits after a backlash.

articles.headline: AOL Chief’s Words Leads to a Study in ‘I’m Sorry’
articles.snippet: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, apologized Saturday for his public remarks about two employees’ “distressed babies.” But was his apology authentic?
articles.abstract: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, apologized Saturday for his public remarks about two employees’ “distressed babies.” But was his apology authentic?

articles.headline: U.S. Debates Drone Strike on American Terrorism Suspect in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The discussion about targeting a citizen, who is believed to be plotting terrorist attacks, is the first time officials have considered killing an American overseas since President Obama imposed limits on drone strikes in May.
articles.abstract: The discussion about targeting a citizen, who is believed to be plotting terrorist attacks, is the first time officials have considered killing an American overseas since President Obama imposed limits on drone strikes in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is debating whether to authorize a lethal strike against an American citizen living in Pakistan who some believe is actively plotting terrorist attacks, according to current and former government officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In West Bank Settlements, Israeli Jobs Are Double-Edged Sword
articles.snippet: Israeli companies in West Bank settlements employ thousands of Palestinians, entrenching the occupation while helping to feed families who oppose it.
articles.abstract: Israeli companies in West Bank settlements employ thousands of Palestinians, entrenching the occupation while helping to feed families who oppose it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISHOR ADUMIM INDUSTRIAL ZONE, West Bank — The personal conflict that thousands of Palestinians face working for Israeli companies in the occupied West Bank is particularly stark for Hassan Jalaita, who for 18 years has repaired Israeli Army jeeps at the Zarfati garage here.

articles.headline: Heroin’s Small-Town Toll, and a Mother’s Grief
articles.snippet: Few understand the way addiction mangles families, said Karen Hale, who lost Alysa Ivy, 21, to an overdose in a Wisconsin town hit hard by heroin.
articles.abstract: Few understand the way addiction mangles families, said Karen Hale, who lost Alysa Ivy, 21, to an overdose in a Wisconsin town hit hard by heroin.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUDSON, Wis. — Karen Hale averts her eyes when she drives past the Super 8 motel in this picturesque riverfront town where her 21-year-old daughter, Alysa Ivy, died of an overdose last May. She has contemplated asking the medical examiner, now a friend, to accompany her there so she could lie on the bed in Room 223 where her child’s body was found.

articles.headline: Yellen Sets a Familiar Direction for the Fed
articles.snippet: In testimony to Congress, Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, gave no sign that policy makers were concerned about recent weak economic data.
articles.abstract: In testimony to Congress, Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, gave no sign that policy makers were concerned about recent weak economic data.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the new chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, told a House committee on Tuesday that she strongly supported and planned to continue the policies adopted under her predecessor, Ben S. Bernanke.

articles.headline: Charter’s Bid for a Deal in Cable Heats Up
articles.snippet: In its most aggressive move yet to take over Time Warner Cable, Charter is proposing a full slate of directors to its target’s board.
articles.abstract: In its most aggressive move yet to take over Time Warner Cable, Charter is proposing a full slate of directors to its target’s board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:16 p.m. | Some corporate takeovers happen in a flash. Others move as slow as molasses.

articles.headline: House Approves Higher Debt Limit Without Condition
articles.snippet: The vote, relying almost entirely on Democrats, ended three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a default was used to wring concessions from President Obama.
articles.abstract: The vote, relying almost entirely on Democrats, ended three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a default was used to wring concessions from President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ending three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a devastating default on the nation’s debt was used to wring conservative concessions from President Obama, the House on Tuesday voted to raise the government’s borrowing limit until March 2015, without any conditions.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker
